跳转到导航 跳转到搜索 向外行动是英国二战期间通过自由飞行的气球攻击德国的计划。它利用了充满氢气的廉价、简单的气球。他们携带的尾随钢丝旨在通过产生短路来损坏高压电力线，或者携带旨在在田野、森林和荒地中引发火灾的燃烧装置。共发射了 99,142 个向外气球；大约一半携带燃烧弹，一半携带拖曳电线。 [a] 与日本比较出名的火气球相比，Outward 气球比较粗糙。他们不得不飞行更短的距离，所以他们在较低的高度飞行——16,000 英尺（4,900 米），而与 38,000 英尺（12,000 米）相比——并且只有一个简单的机制来通过放下压载物或排放提升气体来调节高度.这意味着这些气球易于批量生产，每个只需 35 先令（大约相当于 2021 年的 96 英镑 [3]）。自由飞行的气球攻击非常成功。尽管难以准确评估，但它们对德国的经济影响远远超过了英国政府的成本。 [2] [4] [5] 因为担心如果弹幕气球意外松动会发生什么，英国人在 1937 年进行了一项关于气球携带的电线撞击电力线可能造成的损害的研究。 [2] 早在 1940 年初，负责弹幕气球的组织气球司令部空军副元帅写道：“自战争爆发以来，我一直收到来自电力分销商关于 [弹幕] 气球脱离系泊设施在该国造成的损害。”他补充说：“……可以利用这一点来阻止和给敌人带来不便。” [6] 与此同时，在 1940 年，有人提议可以从法国发射装有炸弹的气球。他们的位置将通过无线电三角测量跟踪，当气球飘过一个有价值的目标时，炸弹将通过无线电控制释放。 [7] 该计划从未付诸实施，反对意见包括“这种性质的攻击不应来自板球国家”，以及担心敌人可能会用类似武器进行报复。 [2] 当法国战役的失败使可能的发射场不受英国控制时，这个想法就变得多余了。 1940 年 9 月 17 日至 18 日晚上，一场大风吹散了一些英国的拦河气球，并将它们吹过北海。在瑞典和丹麦，他们破坏了电力线，扰乱了铁路，并摧毁了瑞典国际广播电台的天线。 [8] [2] 据报道，五个气球已经到达芬兰。 [9] 1940 年 9 月 23 日，英国战争内阁收到了一份关于损坏和混乱的报告。温斯顿·丘吉尔随后指示应调查使用自由飞行的气球作为对抗德国的武器。 [9] [6] 空军部最初发表了一份负面报告，可能是因为飞机生产部认为气球是无效的武器，会消耗太多资源。 [2]
然而，海军部更积极地接受了这个想法。特别是，Boom Defence 主管、使用气球作为进攻武器的支持者 Gerald C. Banister 船长强调了这一点。气象方面的考虑——包括天气可能有利于敌人以实物报复的可能性——经过仔细调查，发现非常有利：16,000 英尺（4,900 米）以上的风往往从西向东吹，这让德国人很难用类似的气球进行报复。 [10] 特别令人感兴趣的是，通过用气球拖曳的细线使高压架空电力线短路，可能会损坏德国的配电网络。再次，调查结果是有利的：试验表明，即使是一根细钢丝，比用来系住静态弹幕气球的钢丝要细得多，当在两个或多个阶段以滑动接触方式拉动时，也可能导致长达 15 英尺的电弧(4.6 m) 并且该电弧将一直保持到断路器断开。在某些情况下，电弧的热量可能会熔化铝制外层，然后熔化导体的钢筋中心绞线。即使电缆没有被切断，导体也会被削弱，因此它们很容易因电力需求增加或风、雪和冰等正常天气事件而断裂。 [6] 调查显示，战前德国通常使用彼得森线圈作为接地保护；这种设计对高压电缆和地之间的短路很有效，但相对容易受到不同相之间短路的影响。相间短路不仅会损坏电缆，还会损坏变压器和断路器本身。 [11] [6] 海军部使用膨胀时直径约 8 英尺（2.4 m）的多余球形乳胶气象气球进行试验。基于试验的计算预测，在沿地面 30 英里（48 公里）的运输过程中，气球电线与高压架空线接触的可能性在 10% 到 75% 之间。气球也可以携带燃烧弹。德国大面积的松树林和荒地使农村容易受到随机燃烧弹的袭击，人们希望德国人将被迫分配大量人员执行看火任务，从而可能使他们无法从事更有成效的战争工作。此外，海军部得出的结论是，气球的生产成本非常低。许多重要部件已经作为剩余材料存在，尽管需要传统的弹幕气球，但仍有大量氢气可以填充气球。 [2] 最后，气球可用于少数面临最小风险的英国人员。使用的气球是多余的气象气球，海军有 100,000 个 [11] 的库存，所有气球都小心地存放在法国粉笔中。使用这些盈余对于“向外行动”的实用性很重要，因为制造它们的白色乳胶橡胶 [12] 是一种供不应求的重要战争材料。气球充气时直径约为 8 英尺（2.4 m）。 [b] 他们携带了一个简单的计时和调节机制，该机制基于为“白化行动”开发的设计——计划在防空任务中使用稍大的乳胶气球。 [c] 发射时，点燃了缓慢燃烧的引信；它的长度被校准为预计到达德国控制领土的时间。起初，气球迅速上升并膨胀，直到内部绳索收紧，通过释放一些气体来防止高度超过 25,000 英尺（7,600 m）；由于氢气逐渐泄漏，气球将开始缓慢下降。 [6] 过了一会儿，缓慢燃烧的引信会在矿物油罐中释放出一个塞子；随着油慢慢滴出，气球的有效载荷会减轻，阻止其下降。同样的缓慢燃烧的引信也被用来释放气球的武器。指定了许多有效载荷设计：电线、啤酒、果冻、袜子、柠檬和果酱。在电线有效载荷的情况下，缓慢燃烧的保险丝会烧穿固定拖曳电线的绳索。拖曳线由约 700 英尺（210 米）、直径为 1⁄ 16 英寸（1.6 毫米）、断裂强度为 40 磅（18 公斤）的麻绳组成。麻绳连接到 300 英尺（91 m）的 0.072 英寸（1.8 毫米）直径（15 号）钢丝上。 [6] 测试表明，拖线被地面障碍物缠住的主要原因是线末端的“弹性”；这是通过获得特殊的拉直线解决的。 [11]
在尾线展开的同时，矿物油罐上的一个塞子被释放出来，以便通过缓慢滴落并减轻气球上的负载来帮助保持高度。 [6] 据计算，气球应该有一个大约 1 磅（0.45 公斤）的轻微负升力，这样气球就会下降，直到一小段电线的重量被地面吸收。长长的麻绳使气球能够保持在大约 1,000 英尺（300 米）的高度，这将减少气球在静止空气中被平静的机会。计划是将线尾拖过乡村约 30 英里（48 公里），最终遇到高压输电线路。 [6] 将引发相间短路；在试验期间，15 英尺 (4.6 m) 长的电弧由导线引发。 [6] 输电线路保护动作前，电弧会燃烧一段时间；断路器本身很可能会损坏，并且导体可能会因电弧而烧穿。这可能会导致线路倒塌并需要维修。德国保护输电线路免受攻击的努力没有成功：新型线路导线夹和不同的过流保护设置都没有任何有用的效果。 [6] 啤酒由一个直径为 8 + 1⁄ 2 英寸（22 厘米）、长 9 英寸（23 厘米）的圆柱形金属容器组成，其中装有七或八个半品脱的瓶子。 [16] 每个瓶子都是自燃磷 (SIP) 手榴弹 [15] - 它含有白磷、苯、水和一条长两英寸（5.1 厘米）的生橡胶，它们溶解并形成一层。在缓慢燃烧的引信造成延迟后，金属容器被打开，里面的东西掉出来了。每个瓶子的颈部周围都有一个小金属套筒，上面装有一个直径约 1 英寸（25 毫米）的重球。 [16] 球附着在一块帆布上； [16] 这确保了当瓶子掉落时，它们会以正确的方式落下。 [17] SIP 手榴弹在破碎时会自发点燃。果冻是罐装燃烧果冻。 [18] 每个长方体的尺寸约为 11 + 1⁄ 2 × 6 + 1⁄ 2 × 4 英寸（29 厘米 × 17 厘米 × 10 厘米），并包含一英制加仑（4.5 升）的果冻。 [19] 提供了一个释放机构和一个保险丝；点火时，一个火球喷出，半径约为 20 英尺（6.1 m）。 [19] 袜子是由燃烧材料制成的细长帆布袋，每袋重约 6 磅（2.7 公斤）。袜子用木丝包裹，用金属丝捆扎，浸泡在沸腾的石蜡中。 [2] [17] 每个向外气球可以携带三只袜子。整个包裹的尺寸约为 27 x 10 x 10 英寸（690 毫米 × 250 毫米 × 250 毫米）。 [19] 掉落时，袜子形成了一个 V 形香肠，旨在抓住树冠。 [2] 保险丝插入设备的每一端，它会从每一端燃烧 15 分钟。 [2] 1941 年，皇家海军有 10,000 只这样的袜子已经融合并准备使用，另外还有 20,000 具尸体可以根据需要提前交付。 [2] [d] 所有有明确代码命名和描述的有效载荷要么是拖曳线，要么是燃烧弹。还使用了从白化行动中遗留下来并重新使用的小型黄色炸弹 [20]，这些炸弹似乎是由这些代码字之一识别的。 [21] 另一个可能是用来丢传单的——记录中偶尔会提到传单，但并不具体。 [2] 在空军部的反对者和海军部的支持者之间进行了长时间的官僚斗争之后，英国参谋长于 1941 年 9 月批准并在皇家海军 HMS Beehive 建立了一个发射场在萨福克郡 Felixstowe 附近的岸边设施。实际的气球释放发生在 Felixstowe Ferry 高尔夫俱乐部。 [22] 第一次发射发生在 1942 年 3 月 20 日。几天之内，英国人就收到了柏林和东普鲁士蒂尔西特附近森林火灾的报告。 [23]
发射气球的人员是 6 名皇家海军和皇家海军军官、80 名皇家海军陆战队、7 名皇家女海军 (WRNS) 军官和 140 名士官。 [2] 该行动还需要英国皇家空军气球司令部（提供和运送氢气）和海军气象部门的协助。 [2] 气球是用来自压力钢瓶的氢气充气的，这些钢瓶是由卡车运到发射场的。它们在三边帐篷或防风林内充气。在充气过程中，必须用水喷雾保持乳胶湿润——否则，气球和帐篷帆布之间的摩擦可能会导致氢气燃烧。充气的气球被人工运送到一个分散点，在那里连接着它们的有效载荷。气球操作可能是危险的，并且有许多发射人员因气球爆炸或对燃烧有效载荷处理不当而导致烧伤而需要住院治疗的事件。 [24] WRNS 配备了“防闪光夹克和头罩（½ 云母和 ½ 细铜纱罩在脸上）+ 手上的防护霜和黑色防火手套。” [e] 出于安全原因，Felixstowe 发射组被称为“Boom-defence”单位，这个封面故事部分属实，因为当天气条件不适合气球发射时，他们被派去维护反潜网. Felixstowe 高尔夫俱乐部场地有许多用于防空的刘易斯枪，WRNS 妇女接受过操作训练，偶尔会释放气球以进行目标练习。 [26] 英国人热衷于评估“向外行动”的有效性。对德国空军通讯的拦截很快显示德国战斗机正试图击落气球。这鼓励了英国人，因为他们认为仅对德国防空系统的骚扰价值就证明了向外行动是合理的——就燃料和飞机磨损而言，德国人摧毁每个气球的成本比英国人制造气球的成本要高.后来，收到的报告显示电力供应受损，森林和农场发生火灾。 [27] 这些报道大多来自丹麦、法国和其他被占领国家的报纸报道，德国当局试图在这些国家以不利的眼光描绘英国的袭击。 [27] 战后，德国的记录显示，拖线袭击给德国人带来了相当大的不便，电力供应经常中断，并严重破坏了配电网络。 [2] 1946 年的一份报告得出结论，根据现有记录，造成了 1,500,000 英镑的损失（大约相当于 2021 年的 5500 万英镑 [3]）。 [4] 报告还指出，实际损失的数量肯定要高得多，因为记录非常不完整，俄罗斯地区没有可用的记录，而且所有记录在 1943 年之后都变得不那么可靠。 [4] 德国人曾试图记录低压线路中断，但事件如此频繁以至于录音被放弃。 [2] 除了派遣战斗机外，德国人还对气球使用防空火力，有时在预计会发生攻击时关闭电缆，并修改高压网络上的断路器。 [2] 1942 年 7 月，第二个发射场在多佛附近的 Oldstairs 湾建立。 [23] 1942 年 7 月 12 日，一个带电线的气球击中了莱比锡附近的 110 kV 电力线。 Böhlen 发电站的断路器故障引发了一场大火，摧毁了该发电站； [1] 这是 Outward 最大的成功。 [6] 燃烧弹袭击的影响非常难以评估——很难判断任何特定的火灾是由 Outward 还是由事故、破坏或飞机投下的燃烧弹引起的。然而，情报来源包括来自被占领欧洲印刷的报纸的报道，表明一些火灾肯定是由 Outward 引起的。 [27] Outward 在中立国造成破坏——1944 年 1 月 19 日至 20 日晚上，两列火车在瑞典的 Laholm 相撞，因为 Outward 气球撞坏了铁路上的电灯。 [1]
变化的风也可能将气球吹回英国。有一次，一个气球摧毁了伊普斯威奇镇的电力供应。 [28] 1942 年 8 月，每天发射达到 1,000 次，后来增加到涉及多达 1,800 个气球的攻击，全部发射时间为三到四个小时。 [27] 气球发射继续进行，但由于担心气球可能会损坏盟军轰炸机，因此在德国发生大规模空袭时，气球发射经常被暂停。 [27] 从 1944 年 5 月起，由于盟军飞机活动的增加，决定改变战术。大规模气球发射被停止，取而代之的是在白天以十分钟为间隔从三个地点发射的“涓涓细流”气球。 [27] 此外，只有 2% 的气球是拖线型的。 [27] “涓流系统”不被认为对盟军飞机构成重大威胁，因此它可以不间断地继续运行。 [27] 涓流系统简化了发射场的氢气供应需求，并释放了对抗德国 V-1 飞弹和诺曼底登陆所需的运输车辆和压缩气瓶。 [27] ^ 消息来源同意总数，但在电线和燃烧弹有效载荷的确切比例方面有所不同，皮布尔斯给燃烧弹的比例略多于一半，[1] 国家档案记录略有不同，但略多于尾随电线。 [2] ^ 一个 8 英尺直径的氢气填充气球可能会提升 18.66 磅（8.46 公斤）。 [13] ^ 白化行动计划使用许多自由气球形成空中雷区。每个 Albino 气球都会携带一根长线，底部有降落伞，顶部有一个黄色的小炸弹。如果飞机抓住了电线，降落伞的阻力会导致炸弹被拉到飞机上，在那里它会在接触时爆炸。白化病进行了尝试，但不是特别成功。 [14] [15] ^ 如果一个向外的气球携带三只袜子，那么记录中提到的 9,644 只袜子的有效载荷几乎完全使用了这种供应。
^ 表格中的数字直接来自国家档案馆的文件。总数加起来不正确，所以记录中肯定有一些错误。 [2] ^ ab 英国零售价格指数通胀数据基于 Clark, Gregory (2017) 的数据。 “英国的年度 RPI 和平均收入，1209 年至今（新系列）”。测量值。 ^ 康沃尔，理查德（2001 年 10 月 26 日）。 “揭晓：气球闪电战的秘密”。伊普斯维奇之星。 Bywater, Sheila Mavis（受访者/演讲者）Smith, Lyn（录音机）（2005 年 8 月 15 日）。 IWM 采访（录音）。帝国战争博物馆。 28452。 Drapeau, Raoul E.（2011 年 9 月至 10 月）。 “向外行动：英国二战的进攻性气球”（PDF）。 IEEE 电力与能源杂志。第 94-105 页。芬利，埃里克·高特 (1994)。 RCN 海滩突击队 W - 第 2 部分：舷窗。理查德·范·威克·劳顿。格贝尔，格雷格 (2019)。 “2.3：二战中的弹幕气球/向外行动”。气球和气球的历史。

Jump to navigation  Jump to search  Operation Outward was a British  World War II program to attack Germany by means of free-flying  balloons. It made use of cheap, simple  balloons filled with hydrogen. They carried either a trailing steel wire intended to damage high voltage  power lines by producing a  short circuit, or incendiary devices that were intended to start fires in fields,  forests and  heathland.
 A total of 99,142 Outward balloons were launched; about half carried incendiaries and half carried trailing wires.  [a]
 Compared to Japan's better-known  fire balloons, Outward balloons were crude. They had to travel a much shorter distance so they flew at a lower altitude – 16,000 feet (4,900 m), compared with 38,000 feet (12,000 m) – and had only a simple mechanism to regulate altitude by means of dropping ballast or venting lifting gas. This meant the balloons were simple to mass-produce and only cost 35  shillings each (approximately equivalent to £96 in 2021  [3]).
 The free flying balloon attacks were highly successful. Although difficult to assess exactly, they had an economic impact on Germany far in excess of the cost to the British government.  [2]  [4]  [5]
    Because there was concern over what could happen if a  barrage balloon accidentally got loose, in 1937 the British carried out a study on the damage that may be caused by a balloon-carried wire hitting power lines.  [2] These concerns were evidently borne out when early in the year 1940, the Air Vice Marshal of the Balloon Command, the organisation responsible for the barrage balloons, wrote that "Since the outbreak of the war, I have had constant complaints from the electricity distributors regarding the damage done in this country by [barrage] balloons that have broken away from their moorings." to which he added "...advantage might be taken of this to impede and inconvenience the enemy."  [6] Meanwhile, in 1940, it was proposed that bomb laden balloons could be launched from France. Their position would be tracked by radio triangulation and the bombs would be released by radio control when the balloon drifted over a worthwhile target.  [7] This plan was never put into action, objections included that "attacks of this nature should not be originated from a cricketing country" and a concern that the enemy might retaliate with similar weapons.  [2] The idea became redundant when defeat in the  Battle of France put possible launch sites out of British control.
  On the night of 17–18 September 1940, a gale broke loose a number of British barrage balloons and carried them across the  North Sea. In Sweden and Denmark, they damaged power lines, disrupted railways and knocked down the antenna for the Swedish International radio station.  [8]  [2] Five balloons were reported to have reached Finland.  [9] A report on the damage and confusion reached the British  War Cabinet on 23 September 1940.  Winston Churchill then directed that the use of free-flying balloons as weapons against Germany should be investigated.  [9]  [6]
 The  Air Ministry initially produced a negative report, possibly because the  Ministry of Aircraft Production felt balloons would be ineffective weapons and would consume too many resources.  [2]
   However, the  Admiralty took up the idea with more enthusiasm. In particular, Captain Gerald C. Banister, Director of Boom Defence and a proponent of using balloons as a weapon of offence, pressed the point. The meteorological considerations – including the possibility that the weather might favour the enemy retaliating in kind – were carefully investigated and found to be highly favourable: winds above 16,000 feet (4,900 m) tend to blow from west to east, making it difficult for the Germans to retaliate with similar balloons.  [10]
 Of particular interest was the possibility of damaging Germany's electricity distribution network by shorting out high-voltage  overhead power lines with thin wires dragged by balloons. Again, the results of investigations were favourable: trials showed that even a thin steel wire, much thinner than that used to tether the static barrage balloons, when drawn in sliding contact across two or more  phases, could cause an arc as long as 15 feet (4.6 m) and that arc would be maintained until the  circuit breaker opened. In some cases, the arc's heat could melt the aluminium outer layers and then the reinforcing steel centre strands of the conductors. Even if the cable was not severed, the conductors would be weakened so that they would be susceptible to breaking due to increased electrical demands or normal weather events such as wind, snow and ice.  [6] Investigations revealed that it was common practice in pre-war Germany to use a  Petersen coil as protection against earthing; this design was effective against a short between a high voltage cable and earth but relatively vulnerable to a short between different phases. A short between phases could result in damage, not just to a cable, but to transformers and the circuit breakers themselves.  [11]  [6] The Admiralty ran trials using surplus spherical latex meteorological balloons about 8 feet (2.4 m) in diameter when inflated. Calculations based on the trials predicted that there would be between a 10% to 75% chance of a balloon's wire coming into contact with a high-voltage overhead line during a 30 miles (48 km) transit along the ground.
 Balloons could also carry incendiaries. Large areas of pine forest and heathland in Germany made the countryside vulnerable to random incendiary attack and it was hoped that the Germans would be forced to assign large numbers of people to the task of  fire watching, possibly diverting them from more productive war-work.
 Furthermore, the Admiralty concluded that the balloons could be produced at very little cost; many of the important parts already existed as surplus materials, and despite the needs of conventional barrage balloons, there was plenty of hydrogen gas with which to fill the balloons.  [2] Finally, the balloons could be used with a small number of British personnel who would face minimal risks.
  The balloons used were surplus weather balloons of which the Navy had a stock of 100,000  [11] all carefully stored in  French chalk. Using this surplus was important to the practicality of Operation Outward because white latex rubber from which they were made  [12] was an important war material that was in short supply. The balloons were about 8 feet (2.4 m) in diameter when inflated.  [b] They carried a simple timing and regulating mechanism that was based upon a design developed for  Operation Albino – a plan to use somewhat larger latex balloons in an anti-aircraft role.  [c] At launch, a  slow-burning fuse was lit; its length was calibrated to the estimated time to arrive over German-controlled territory. At first, the balloon rose rapidly and expanded in size until an internal cord tightened, preventing further increase in altitude beyond 25,000 feet (7,600 m) by releasing some gas; the balloon would then begin a slow descent due to the hydrogen gradually leaking away.  [6] After a while, the slow burning fuse would release a bung in a can of mineral oil; as the oil slowly dripped out, the balloon's payload would lighten, arresting its descent. The same slow-burning fuse was also used to release the balloon's weapon.
 There were a number of payload designs designated:  wire,  beer,  jelly,  socks,  lemon and  jam.
   In the case of the  wire payload, the slow burning fuse would burn through the cord that held the trailing wire. The trailing wire consisted of about 700 feet (210 m) of   1⁄ 16 inch (1.6 mm) diameter hemp cord with a breaking strength of 40 pounds (18 kg). The hemp cord was attached to 300 feet (91 m) of 0.072-inch (1.8 mm) diameter ( 15 gauge) steel wire.  [6] Tests had revealed that the main reason for the trailing wire getting caught up in ground obstacles was "springiness" at the end of the wires; this was addressed by obtaining special straightened wire.  [11]
 At the same time as the trailing wire was deployed, a stopper on the canister of mineral oil was released so that it would assist in maintaining altitude by slowly dripping out and lightening the load on the balloon.  [6] It was calculated that the balloon should have a slightly negative lift of about 1 pound (0.45 kg) so that the balloon would descend until a short length of the wire had its weight taken by the ground. The long length of hemp cord allowed the balloon to maintain an altitude of about 1,000 feet (300 m) which would reduce the chance of the balloon being becalmed in still air.
 The plan was that the wire tail would be dragged for about 30 miles (48 km) across the countryside and eventually encounter a high-voltage transmission line.  [6] A phase-to-phase short circuit would be initiated; during trials, arcs 15 feet (4.6 m) long were initiated by the wire.  [6] The arc would burn for some time before the transmission line protection operated; there was a good chance the circuit breaker itself would be damaged and the conductors might burn through due to arcing. This could cause a line to collapse and require repairs. German efforts to protect transmission lines from attack were unsuccessful: neither a new type of line conductor clamp nor different overcurrent protection settings had any useful effect.  [6]
    Beer consisted of a cylindrical metal container   8 + 1⁄ 2 inches (22 cm) in diameter and 9 inches (23 cm) long containing seven or eight half-pint bottles.  [16] Each bottle was a  Self-igniting phosphorus (SIP) grenade  [15] – it contained  white phosphorus,  benzene, water and a strip of raw  rubber, two inches (5.1 cm) long, which dissolved and formed a layer. After a delay caused by a  slow burning fuse, the metal container was tipped open and its contents allowed to fall out. Around the neck of each bottle was a small metal sleeve that held a heavy ball about one inch (25 mm) in diameter.  [16] The ball was attached to a strip of canvas;  [16] this ensured that when the bottles dropped they fell the right way round.  [17] The SIP grenades would spontaneously ignite on shattering.
 Jelly were cans of incendiary jelly.  [18] Each cuboid can measured about   11 + 1⁄ 2 by  6 + 1⁄ 2 by 4 inches (29 cm × 17 cm × 10 cm) and contained one imperial gallon (4.5 l) of jelly.  [19] A release mechanism and a fuse were provided; on ignition a fireball erupted with a radius of about 20 feet (6.1 m).  [19]
 Socks were long thin canvas bags of incendiary material each weighing about 6 pounds (2.7 kg). Socks were packed with  wood wool, bound with wire and soaked in boiling  paraffin wax.  [2]  [17] Each Outward balloon could carry three socks. The whole bundle measured about 27 by 10 by 10 inches (690 mm × 250 mm × 250 mm).  [19] When dropped, socks formed a V‑shaped sausage designed to catch in the crown of a tree.  [2] Fuses were inserted in each end of the device and it would burn from each end for 15 minutes.  [2] In 1941 the Royal Navy had a stock of 10,000 such socks already fused and ready to be used and another 20,000 bodies that could be brought forward as required.  [2]  [d]
    All the payloads that are clearly code named and described are either a trailing wire or an incendiary.  Small yellow bombs left over and re-purposed from  Operation Albino were also used  [20] and it seems likely that these are identified by one of these code words.  [21] It is possible that the other was used to drop leaflets – there are occasional, but nonspecific, mentions of leaflet drops in the records.  [2]
  After a lengthy bureaucratic struggle between the opponents in the Air Ministry and proponents in the Admiralty, the British  Chiefs of Staff gave the go‑ahead in September 1941 and a launch site was set up, based at HMS  Beehive, a Royal Navy  shore establishment near  Felixstowe in  Suffolk. The actual  balloon releases took place at the  Felixstowe Ferry Golf Club.  [22] The first launches took place on 20 March 1942. Within days, the British were receiving reports of forest fires near  Berlin and  Tilsit in  East Prussia.  [23]
 The personnel that launched the balloons were six Royal Navy and Royal Marine officers, 80 Royal Marines, 7  Women's Royal Naval Service (WRNS) officers and 140 non-commissioned WRNS.  [2] The operation also required the assistance of the  RAF Balloon Command (that supplied and delivered the hydrogen) and the Naval Meteorological Services.  [2] The balloons were inflated using hydrogen from pressure cylinders that were brought to the launch site by truck. They were inflated inside three-sided tents or windbreaks. During inflation, it was necessary to keep the latex wet with a water spray – otherwise, friction between the balloon and the tent canvas might have caused the hydrogen to ignite. The inflated balloons were conveyed by hand to a dispersal point, where their payload was attached. Balloon operations could be hazardous, and there were many incidences of launch crew requiring hospital treatment for burns caused by exploding balloons or by mishandling incendiary payloads.  [24] The WRNS were equipped with "flash-proof jacket & hood (½ mica & ½ fine copper gauze over the face) + protective cream on hands and fire-proof black gloves."  [e]
 For security reasons, the Felixstowe launch crews were referred to as a "Boom-defence" unit, a cover story that was partly true as they were put to work maintaining  anti-submarine nets when weather conditions were not right for balloon launches. The Felixstowe golf club site had a number of  Lewis Guns for anti-aircraft defence, which the WRNS women were trained to operate, occasionally releasing balloons for the purpose of target practice.  [26]
   The British were keen to assess the effectiveness of Operation Outward. Intercepts of  Luftwaffe communications soon showed German fighters were trying to shoot down balloons. This encouraged the British as it was felt that the harassment value on German air defences alone justified Operation Outward – it cost the Germans more, in terms of fuel and wear and tear on aircraft, to destroy each balloon than it cost the British to make them. Later, reports were received revealing damage to electricity supplies and fires in forests and on farms.  [27] Most of these reports were harvested from newspaper reports in Denmark, France and other occupied countries where the German authorities tried to paint the British attacks in an unfavourable light.  [27]
 After the war, German records revealed that the trailing wire attacks had caused the Germans considerable inconvenience with electricity supplies frequently being interrupted and significant damage to the electrical distribution network.  [2] A 1946 report concluded that, based on available records, £1,500,000 of damage was done (approximately equivalent to £55 million in 2021  [3]).  [4] The report also stated that the actual amount of damage must have been far higher because the records were very incomplete with no available records for the Russian zone and all records becoming less reliable after 1943.  [4] The Germans had attempted to record interrupts to the lower voltage lines, but the incidents were so frequent that the recording was abandoned.  [2] In addition to sending up fighters, the Germans used anti-aircraft fire against the balloons, sometimes shut down electric cables when an attack was anticipated, and modified the circuit breakers on high voltage networks.  [2]
 In July 1942, a second launch site was set up at Oldstairs Bay near  Dover.  [23] On 12 July 1942, a wire-carrying balloon struck a 110 kV power line near  Leipzig. A failure in the  circuit breaker at the  Böhlen power station caused a fire that destroyed the station;  [1] this was Outward's greatest success.  [6]
 The effects of the incendiary attacks were very difficult to assess – it could be difficult to tell whether any particular fire was caused by  Outward or by an accident, sabotage, or aircraft-dropped incendiary. However, intelligence sources included reports from newspapers printed in occupied Europe indicated that some fires had definitely been caused by Outward.  [27]
 Outward caused damage in neutral countries – on the night of 19–20 January 1944, two trains collided at  Laholm in Sweden after an Outward balloon knocked out electrical lighting on the railway.  [1]
 Changing winds could also blow balloons back to the United Kingdom. On one occasion, a balloon knocked out the electricity supply to the town of  Ipswich.  [28]
  In August 1942, launches reached 1,000 per day, and later increased to attacks involving up to 1,800 balloons all launched over a period of three to four hours.  [27] Balloon launches continued, though they were frequently suspended when there were large air-raids on Germany as it was feared the balloons might damage Allied bombers.  [27]
 From May 1944 it was decided to change tactics because of increased Allied aircraft activity. The mass balloon launches were stopped and replaced with a "trickle" of balloons launched from three sites at ten-minute intervals throughout daylight hours.  [27] Furthermore, only 2% of the balloons were to be of the trailing wire type.  [27] The "trickle system" was not thought to be a significant threat to Allied aircraft so it could go on uninterrupted.  [27] The trickle system simplified the hydrogen supply requirements of the launch sites, and released transport vehicles and compressed gas cylinders needed for  operations against German V-1 flying bombs and for the  Normandy landings.  [27]

If an aircraft caught the wire, the drag of the parachute would cause the bomb to be drawn down onto the aircraft where it would explode on contact. Albino was tried out, but was not particularly successful.  [14]  [15]
